sorcer.util

Class SorcerEnv

  • java.lang.Object
    • sorcer.util.SOS
      • sorcer.util.SorcerEnv
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    Sorcer

    public class SorcerEnv
extends SOS
    The Sorcer utility class provides the global environment configuration for the SORCER environment. The class is initialized only once by a static initializer when the Sorcer class is loaded.

    This includes all the information that is specific to the SORCER environment and is shared among all provider components or even across multiple providers.

    The information is collected from iGrid/config/sorcer.env mainly and can be updated by specific values from a provider Jini configuration file, provider properties file, and JVM system properties.

    A sorcer.env file is searched for in the SorcerEnv.class directory (sorcer/util/sorcer.env), or in the path given by the JVM system property sorcer.env.file. In development the last option is recommended.

    The priorities for loading properties are as follows:

    1. First, SORCER environment properties (sorcer.env) are read by the ServiceProvider
    2. Second, provider configuration defined in Jini configuration file is loaded and it can override any relevant settings in the existing Sorcer object. Provider specific configuration is collected in ProviderConfig ProviderDelegate.
    3. Third, application-specific provider properties are loaded if specified by attribute properties in the Jini configuration file and they can override relevant sorcer.env properties. While a collection of Jini configuration properties is predefined, in the provider properties file, custom properties can be defined and accessed via ServiceProvider.getProperty(String key).
    4. Finally, JVM system properties (sorcer.env.file), if specified, can override settings in the existing Env object.

    The SORCER environment includes context data types. These types are similar to MIME types and are loaded like the environment properties sorcer.env described above. They associate applications to a format of data contained in context data nodes. Data types can be either loaded from a file (default name data.formats) or database. A JVM system property sorcer.formats.file can be used to indicate the location and name of a data type file. Data types are defined in service contexts by a particular composite attribute dnt|application|modifiers, see examples in iGrid/data.formats. Data type associations (for example dnt|etds|object|Hashtable.output) can be used to lookup data nodes in service contexts Contexts.getMarkedPaths.

    Author:
    M. W. Sobolewski

      • loadDataFormatTypes

        protected static void loadDataFormatTypes(java.lang.String filename)
                                   throws ConfigurationException
        Loads data node (eval) types from the SORCER data store or file. Data node types specify application types of data nodes in service contexts. It is analogous to MIME types in SORCER. Each type has a format 'cnt/application/format/modifiers' or in the association format 'cnt|application|format|modifiers' when used with Context.getMarkedPaths.
        Parameters:
        filename - name of file containing service context node type definitions.
        Throws:
        ConfigurationException

      • getAnonymousPort

        public static int getAnonymousPort()
                            throws java.io.IOException
        Get an anonymous port.
        Returns:
        An anonymous port created by invoking getPortAvailable(). Once this method is called the return eval is setValue statically for future reference
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If there are problems getting the anonymous port

      • getPortAvailable

        public static int getPortAvailable()
                            throws java.io.IOException
        Get an anonymous port
        Returns:
        An available port created by instantiating a java.net.ServerSocket with a port of 0
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If an available port cannot be obtained

                                         throws java.net.UnknownHostException

                                                      java.util.Properties properties,
                                                      boolean expanding)
                                               throws ConfigurationException
        Expands properties embedded in a string with ${some.property.name}. Also treats ${/} as ${file.separator}.
        Throws:
